message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of medial joint tenderness, erythema, and clicking sensation along with the absence of anterior displacement in the anterior drawer test suggests damage to the medial meniscus. The anterior drawer test is used to assess for damage to the anterior cruciate ligament, which is not found to be damaged in this patient. The medial collateral ligament and lateral meniscus may also be injured in cases of knee trauma, but in this patient, the clinical presentation and exam findings suggest damage to the medial meniscus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with a medial meniscus tear. The clicking of the joint and absence of anterior displacement on the anterior drawer test help rule out an ACL tear.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the symptoms, the most likely structure that is damaged in this patient is the medial meniscus. Medial joint tenderness, subtle clicking, and locking are all signs of meniscal injury. The absent anterior displacement of the tibia on the anterior drawer test rules out an Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) injury. The lateral meniscus and medial collateral ligament (MCL) are less likely to be injured based on the patient’s symptoms and physical examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings suggest a medial meniscus tear. Medial joint tenderness, erythema and bruising, clicking of the joint, and an antalgic gait are all indicative of a meniscal injury. Absent anterior displacement of the tibia on an anterior drawer test rules out an anterior cruciate ligament injury. A medial collateral ligament injury would cause tenderness along the medial aspect of the knee, but would not cause joint clicking or locking. The lateral meniscus is less commonly injured than the medial meniscus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain and tenderness, as well as the clicking of the joint, suggest damage to the medial meniscus. This is further supported by the absence of anterior displacement on the anterior drawer test, which rules out damage to the anterior cruciate ligament. The medial collateral ligament may also be damaged, but this would not explain the clicking of the joint.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of pain, locking, and clicking, as well as the physical exam findings of medial joint tenderness and antalgic gait, suggest damage to the medial meniscus. The absent anterior displacement on an anterior drawer test indicates that there is no damage to the anterior cruciate ligament. The medial collateral ligament and lateral meniscus may also be injured in a knee injury, but the specific symptoms and exam findings in this patient suggest medial meniscus damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings, particularly the medial joint tenderness and subtle clicking of the joint, suggest a medial meniscus injury. The absence of an anterior displacement on an anterior drawer test suggests that the anterior cruciate ligament is intact. None of the other options are consistent with the given exam findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, such as locking of the knee, clicking of the joint, tenderness of the medial joint, and absent anterior displacement on an anterior drawer test, suggest a tear in the medial meniscus. The other options are less likely to cause these specific symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including knee locking and medial joint tenderness, are indicative of a medial meniscus injury. A positive anterior drawer test would suggest an anterior cruciate ligament injury, but the test is negative in this case. The other options are less likely to be damaged based on the patient's symptoms and exam findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings suggest damage to the medial meniscus. The erythema, bruising, and antalgic gait are indicative of inflammation and pain in the joint, and the subtle clicking on passive range of motion suggests a meniscal tear. The absent anterior displacement on the anterior drawer test rules out damage to the anterior cruciate ligament. The absence of tenderness over the lateral side of the joint rules out damage to the lateral meniscus and collateral ligaments.
